metadata.case_name: Bombay Union of Journalists & Ors. v. State of Bombay & Anr.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 Mrs. Aruna Mukherji appointed on the staff of respondent No. 2 on a salary of Rs. 500 p.m. with effect from 1st January, 1955.

On 30th November, 1957, appellant No. 2 served with notice of termination of services with effect from 1st December, 1957. Notice recited management in consultation with Editor decided to retrench her services under section 3(2) of Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955, paid salaries for three months in lieu of notice.

Appellant No. 3 Mr. M. T. Thomas employed as Sub-Editor in Free Press Journal some time in 1953, served with similar notice of retrenchment dated 30th November, 1957, terminated as from 1st December, 1957, under section 3(2) of Working Journalists Act, paid three months salaries in lieu.
Both appellants collected salaries for November 1957 and ceased to work for respondent No. 2 from 1st December, 1957.

Appellant No. 1 (Bombay Union of Journalists) wrote to Director-in-charge of respondent No. 2 on 3rd December, 1957, complaining action smacked of vindictiveness, demanded withdrawal of notices and reinstatement.
Respondent No. 2 did not accede to demand. Appellant No. 1 moved Labour Commissioner of respondent No. 1.
Conciliation Officer intervened, called parties, discussions held, no settlement possible, submitted failure report under s.12(4) of Act on 15th April, 1958, opining no possibility of settlement.

Parties filed statements before respondent No. 1. Respondent No. 1 considered statements and report, concluded not necessary to refer dispute to Tribunal under s.12(5), communicated by letter dated 1st July, 1958 from Dy. Secretary, reasons: termination was retrenchment, management willing to pay dues, no mala fide, vindictiveness or victimisation.
Appellants moved Bombay High Court under Art. 226 for writ of mandamus against respondent No. 1, urging refusal illegal, prayed direction to reconsider.
Writ petition dismissed by single Judge. Letters Patent Appeal to Division Bench dismissed, agreed with single Judge.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated September 10, 1960 in Appeal No. 10 of 1959.
No notice served by respondent No. 2 on respondent No. 1 under s.25F(c) prior to termination.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appropriate Government acted illegally by considering the merits of the dispute while refusing reference under s.12(5) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
Whether respondent No. 1 failed to consider non-compliance with s.25F(c).
Construction of s.25F(c) of Industrial Disputes Act: whether it constitutes a mandatory condition precedent for valid retrenchment like clauses (a) and (b).

petitioner_arguments.text: Reasons given by respondent No. 1 show it considered merits of dispute, acted illegally and improperly under s.12(5).
Respondent No. 1 did not consider failure to comply with s.25F(c), introducing infirmity.
S.25F(c) is mandatory condition precedent like (a) and (b), negative form and 'until' indicate conditions must be satisfied before retrenchment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 25F Industrial Disputes Act; State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha; Tea Districts Labour Assoc. v. Ex-Employees; Workmen of Subong Tea Estate v. Outgoing Management

respondent_arguments.text: Termination was retrenchment, management paid legal dues, no mala fide, vindictiveness or victimisation for trade union activities.

court_reasoning.text: Appropriate Government can consider prima facie merits under s.10(1) read with s.12(5), not final decisions on law or facts, but expedient or not; if claim frivolous, belated, or adverse impact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt entitled to prima facie examination; cited State of Bombay v. K.P. Krishnan.

court_reasoning.text: Govt not required to consider every plea exhaustively; Rule 80 treats s.25F(c) notice as condition subsequent when paid in lieu; court not in appeal over reasons unless irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No infirmity in omission to mention s.25F(c).

court_reasoning.text: S.25F(c) not condition precedent: payment in lieu under (a) allows immediate retrenchment, notice after; rules consistent; object informational for govt, unlike protective (a),(b); negative form and 'until' satisfied post-retrenchment.
Even if s.25F(c) mandatory precedent, govt not bound to refer; discretion under s.10(1)/12(5) unless mala fide.

holdings.text: Appropriate Government may prima facie consider merits when deciding reference under s.10(1) read with s.12(5).
Omission to expressly consider s.25F(c) not fatal given govt's Rule 80 and discretion.
S.25F(c) does not constitute condition precedent for valid retrenchment.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. K. P. Krishnan & Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt may consider prima facie merits for reference expediency.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay & Others v. The Hospital Mazdoor Sabha & Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: S.25F(b) mandatory condition precedent; noted (a),(c) similar but not decided.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tea Districts Labour Association, Calcutta v. Ex-Employees of Tea Districts Labour Association and Anr.
Workmen of Subong Tea Estate v. The Outgoing Management of Subong Tea Estate & Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter: three conditions of s.25F prima facie precedent.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs conciliation, reference discretion, retrenchment conditions; s.25F(c) directory post-retrenchment notice.

statutes_cited.name: Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition in High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed, upholding Bombay High Court's dismissal of writ petition; government's refusal to refer dispute justified as it considered prima facie merits and s.25F(c) not condition precedent.

key_quotes.text: "the appropriate Government may consider, prima facie, the merits of the dispute and take into account other relevant considerations which would help it to decide whether making a reference would be expedient or not."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of govt's power under s.10(1)/12(5).

key_quotes.text: "s.25F(c) cannot be held to be a condition precedent even though it has been included under s.25F along with clauses (a) and (b) which prescribe conditions precedent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction of s.25F(c).

key_quotes.text: "Clause (c) is not intended to protect the interests of the workman as such. It is only intended to give intimation to the appropriate Government about the retrenchment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
